slidelink.displaytext: Untitled Scene
Untitled Slide

Hemostasis is a process by which the body spontaneously stops bleeding and maintains blood in a fluid form. There are two system to help with that.
Which system involving vascular system and platelets, activated by small vessel damage?
Drag and Drop
A damage to the vessel, exposes:
Normal platelet count is 150,000 to 450,000. Where is one-third of its volume stored in the body?
Primary hemostasis is the process of platelet plug formation.

Platelet adehesion occurs when platelet attach to collagen in the exposed basement membrane.
Platelets required all of the option to adhere, accept for:
Drag and Drop
Thrombocytopenia is considered when platelets are low. Bleeding may occur less than or nearly equal to how many platelets?
In evaluation of platelets, Which of these can interfere with platelet accuracy evaluation?
In Amplification of platelets, which substance will recruit more platelets to the site of injury?
In platelets aggregation, Platelets stick to each other using fibrinogen. fibrinogen attaches to platelets at which site?
In second hemostasis, tissue factor activates which factor?
In coagulation cascade, all the options are inhibitors of the common pathway, except for:
In coagulation cascade, all the options are activators of the common pathway, except for:

Coagulation cascade - Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways both can activate common pathway.
Organize the common pathway.
Coagulation cascade Organize the intrinsic pathway by dragging the circles in the correct place.
Coagulation cascade Organize the extrinsic pathway by dragging the circles in the correct place.
In coagulation cascade, all the options are activators of the common pathway, except for:
Match the common pathway coagulation vocabulary
In initiation phase of coagulation,Tissue factor bearing cells interact with which factor?
In amplification phase of platelets, which of these activates platelets?
In termination phase of coagulation, which of these clotting process initiate a stop of coagulation in order to prevent occlusion of the vessel?
Which factor acts on fibrin polymers to create the final cross-linked stable fibrin clot?
Which factor is activated by thrombin bound to thrombomodulin and is a regulatory inhibitor?
This is a cofactor that participate conversion of protein C → activated protein C (A P C). What is this regulatory factor?
Which inactivation factor work as an anticoagulant (plasma protein), and inactivates factor Va – V and VIIa – VII to stop clotting.
What inhibits the activator protein C (APC)?
What factors inhibits the inhibits VII a/T F and X a?
What factors is a direct thrombin inhibitor?

In Fibrinolytic System, Fibrinolytic and antifibrinolytic factors allow blood clots to dissolve.
What is the primary fibrinolytic factor that converts to plasmin through t P A and urokinase-like?

In Fibrinolytic System, Fibrinolytic and antifibrinolytic factors allow blood clots to dissolve.
What Breaks down fibrin clot creating fragments like fibrin split products (F S P’s)?

In Fibrinolytic System
A deficiency in fibrinolytic factors can cause which of the options below?

In Fibrinolytic System
Deficiency of antifibrinolytic factors can cause which of the options below?

Which of these tests measure extrinsic and common pathways? Reagent used: tissue factor, platelet phospholipid, and calcium
Measures Warfarin or acute bleeding

Screen tests to evaluate bleeding
Which of these tests Screens for intrinsic and common pathways? Used to monitor unfractionated heparin

In this test, Patient plasma is mixed 1:1 with pooled normal plasma and the abnormal PT, APPT test. The PNP has to be platelet poor <5,000
What is the rest?

Mixing studies is used to evaluate abnormal P T and A P T T or other issue going on in circulation.
Corrected repeat P T or A P T T indicate which of the below?
Mixing studies is used to evaluate abnormal P T and A P T T or identify a factor deficiency vs a circulating inhibitor A Corrected repeat P T indicate which of the below?
Mixing studies is used to evaluate abnormal P T and A P T T or identify a factor deficiency vs a circulating inhibitor A P T not corrected indicate which option below?
Mixing studies is used to evaluate abnormal P T and A P T T or identify a factor deficiency vs a circulating inhibitor Corrected A P T T indicate which of the below?

Screen tests to evaluate bleeding
PT test is exclusive for determining deficiency in which factor?

International normalized ratio (I N R) Used to standardize P T reporting for monitoring anticoagulant therapy.
What is the WHO IRP standard value?

International normalized ratio (I N R)
The closer the P T is to the I R P standard, the more sensitive the reagent. What is the International Sensitivity reference value indicating a sensitive response of the reagent thromboplastin, used for testing?
Coagulation samples drawn into light blue–top tubes, contain:
If CBC in an EDTA sample is needed a platelet count, how would you proceed?
Thrombocytopenia is lead by?
Thrombocytosis - Platelet count is greater than 450 multiplied by 10⁹/liter. What is a primary causes below?

Thrombocytopenia can be related to antibody to platelet products containing H P A-1a, H P A-5, or H P A-15 (rare).
Which condition is it?

Thrombocytopenia can be related to Maternal antibody to infant’s platelets from an earlier pregnancy.
Which condition is it?

Thrombocytopenia that is related to Autoantibody (I g G) against G P II b or III A or G P Ib-IX
Which condition is it?

Thrombocytopenia that is related Microangiopathic anemia (M H A) Fever, Neurologic symptoms, Visual impairment, Renal dysfunction
Which condition is it?

Thrombocytopenia with Schistocytes and severe anemia, Increased L D H Decreased haptoglobin, Hemoglobinuria, Renal dysfunction may occur.
Which condition is it?

Thrombocytopenia on a 6 months to 4 years old Mimics T T P (no neurologic symptoms) but more severe renal damage Renal damage caused by toxin produced by E. coli O157:H7 or Shigella
Which condition is it?
An acute Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (I T P) would be caused by?
Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (I T P) is caused by a deficiency in
Secondary to an intrinsic defect of platelets Match the platelets defects.

Autosomal recessive Rare adhesion defect of platelets involving G P I b–IX complex
What condition is it?

Rare autosomal recessive disorder Deficiency or abnormality of G P II b and III a Fibrinogen binding to platelets (platelet aggregation)
What condition is it?

Autosomal recessive Dense granules deficient Results in albinism and hemorrhagic events
What condition is it?

Autosomal recessive Giant lysosomal granules in neutrophils Frequent infections because of impaired phagocytic ability Thrombocytopenia
What condition is it?

Abnormalities due drug-related. Aspirin (most commonly used)
What condition is it?
Which of the options is considered a Extrinsic platelet abnormality?

Platelets lack alpha granules Platelets are gray or blue-gray color in P S Large platelet Bleeding tendencies Bruisability
What condition is it?
X-linked recessive disorder Severe eczema Recurrent infections Immune defects What condition is it?
Rare disorder Skeletal and cardiac abnormalities What condition is it?

Autosomal recessive Rare adhesion defect of platelets involving G P I b–IX complex
G P I b–IX is a site for:

Autosomal dominant, it gets the help of factor VIII to get to peripheral circulation. This condition cause easy bruising, nosebleeds, heavy menses, excessive bleeding after tooth extraction or dental procedures.
What is it?
All options are way to measure vWF protein but which one is the best predictive assay?
Which one is the subtype of type 2 vWD?
What is the treatment for vWD?
